message_completed <- function(x, in_builder = FALSE) {
  if (isFALSE(in_builder)) {
    str <- paste0(my_time(), " | ", x)
    usethis::ui_done("{usethis::ui_field(str)}")
  } else if (in_builder) {
    usethis::ui_done("{my_time()} | {x}")
  }
}

user_message <- function(x, type) {
  if (type == "done") {
    usethis::ui_done("{my_time()} | {x}")
  } else if (type == "todo") {
    usethis::ui_todo("{my_time()} | {x}")
  } else if (type == "info") {
    usethis::ui_info("{my_time()} | {x}")
  } else if (type == "oops") {
    usethis::ui_oops("{my_time()} | {x}")
  }
}

my_time <- function() strftime(Sys.time(), format = "%H:%M:%S")

# custom mode function from https://stackoverflow.com/questions/2547402/is-there-a-built-in-function-for-finding-the-mode/8189441
custom_mode <- function(x, na.rm = TRUE) {
  if(na.rm){x <- x[!is.na(x)]}
  ux <- unique(x)
  return(ux[which.max(tabulate(match(x, ux)))])
}

# read qs files form an url
qs_from_url <- function(url) qs::qdeserialize(curl::curl_fetch_memory(url)$content)

# read rds that has been pre-fetched
read_raw_rds <- function(raw) {
  con <- gzcon(rawConnection(raw))
  ret <- readRDS(con)
  close(con)
  return(ret)
}

# helper to make sure the output of the
# schedule scraper is not named 'invalid' if the source file not yet exists
maybe_valid <- function(id) {
  all(
    length(id) == 1,
    is.character(id),
    substr(id, 1, 4) %in% seq.int(1999, as.integer(format(Sys.Date(), "%Y")) + 1, 1),
    as.integer(substr(id, 6, 7)) %in% seq_len(22),
    str_extract_all(id, "(?<=_)[:upper:]{2,3}")[[1]] %in% nflfastR::teams_colors_logos$team_abbr
  )
}

# check if a package is installed
is_installed <- function(pkg) requireNamespace(pkg, quietly = TRUE)

# load Lee Sharpe's games file
load_lees_games <- function(){
  con <- url("https://github.com/leesharpe/nfldata/blob/master/data/games.rds?raw=true")
  dat <- readRDS(con)
  close(con)
  dat
}

# load raw game files esp. for debugging
load_raw_game <- function(game_id, qs = FALSE){
  
  if (isTRUE(qs) && !is_installed("qs")) {
    usethis::ui_stop("Package {usethis::ui_value('qs')} required for argument {usethis::ui_value('qs = TRUE')}. Please install it.")
  }
  
  season <- substr(game_id, 1, 4)
  path <- "https://raw.githubusercontent.com/guga31bb/nflfastR-raw/master/raw"
  
  if(isFALSE(qs)) fetched <- curl::curl_fetch_memory(glue::glue("{path}/{season}/{game_id}.rds"))
  
  if(isTRUE(qs)) fetched <- curl::curl_fetch_memory(glue::glue("{path}/{season}/{game_id}.qs"))
  
  if (fetched$status_code == 404 & maybe_valid(game_id)) {
    usethis::ui_stop("The requested GameID {game_id} is not loaded yet, please try again later!")
  } else if (fetched$status_code == 500) {
    usethis::ui_stop("The data hosting servers are down, please try again later!")
  } else if (fetched$status_code == 404) {
    usethis::ui_stop("The requested GameID {game_id} is invalid!")
  }
  
  if(isFALSE(qs)) raw_data <- read_raw_rds(fetched$content)
  
  if(isTRUE(qs)) raw_data <- qs::qdeserialize(fetched$content)
  
  return(raw_data)
  
}

# Identify sessions with sequential future resolving
is_sequential <- function() inherits(future::plan(), "sequential")

check_stat_ids <- function(seasons, stat_ids){
  
  if (is_sequential()) {
    usethis::ui_info(c(
      "It is recommended to use parallel processing when using this function.",
      "Please consider running {usethis::ui_code('future::plan(\"multisession\")')}!",
      "Will go on sequentially..."
    ))
  }
  
  games <- load_lees_games() %>%
    dplyr::filter(!is.na(.data$result), .data$season %in% seasons) %>%
    dplyr::pull(.data$game_id)
  
  p <- progressr::progressor(along = games)
  
  furrr::future_map_dfr(games, function(id, stats, p){
    raw_data <- load_raw_game(id)
    plays <- janitor::clean_names(raw_data$data$viewer$gameDetail$plays) %>%
      dplyr::select(.data$play_id, .data$play_stats)
    
    p(sprintf("ID=%s", as.character(id)))
    
    tidyr::unnest(plays, cols = c("play_stats")) %>%
      janitor::clean_names() %>%
      dplyr::filter(.data$stat_id %in% stats) %>%
      dplyr::mutate(game_id = as.character(id)) %>%
      dplyr::select(
        "game_id",
        "play_id",
        "stat_id",
        "yards",
        "team_abbr" = "team_abbreviation",
        "player_name",
        "gsis_player_id"
      )
  }, stat_ids, p)
}

# compute most recent season
most_recent_season <- function() {
  dplyr::if_else(
    lubridate::month(lubridate::today("America/New_York")) >= 9,
    lubridate::year(lubridate::today("America/New_York")),
    lubridate::year(lubridate::today("America/New_York")) - 1
  )
}

# Load Next Gen Stats from Github -----------------------------------------

load_ngs <- function(seasons, type) {
  if (!type %in% c("passing", "rushing", "receiving")) usethis::ui_stop('Please pass valid type ("passing", "rushing" or "receiving")!')
  
  most_recent <- most_recent_season()
  
  if (!all(seasons %in% 2016:most_recent)) {
    usethis::ui_stop("Please pass valid seasons between 2016 and {most_recent}")
  }
  
  if (length(seasons) > 1 && is_sequential()) {
    usethis::ui_info(c(
      "It is recommended to use parallel processing when trying to load multiple seasons.",
      "Please consider running {usethis::ui_code('future::plan(\"multisession\")')}!",
      "Will go on sequentially..."
    ))  }
  
  p <- progressr::progressor(along = seasons)
  
  out <- furrr::future_map_dfr(seasons, single_season_ngs, type, p)
  
  return(out)
}

single_season_ngs <- function(season, type, p, qs = FALSE) {
  
  if (isTRUE(qs)){
    .url <- glue::glue("https://github.com/mrcaseb/nfl-data/blob/master/data/ngs/ngs_{season}_{type}.qs?raw=true")
    ret <- qs_from_url(.url)
  }
  if (isFALSE(qs)) {
    .url <- glue::glue("https://github.com/mrcaseb/nfl-data/blob/master/data/ngs/ngs_{season}_{type}.rds?raw=true")
    con <- url(.url)
    ret <- readRDS(con)
    close(con)
  }
  
  p(sprintf("season=%g", season))
  return(ret)
}
Clean_pbp <- function(pbp_fastr, ...) {
  if (nrow(pbp_fastr) == 0) {
    user_message("Nothing to clean. Return passed data frame.", "info")
    r <- pbp_fastr
  } else{
    user_message("Cleaning up play-by-play...", "todo")
    
    # drop existing values of clean_pbp
    pbp <- pbp_fastr %>% dplyr::select(-tidyselect::any_of(drop.cols))
    
    r <- pbp %>%
      dplyr::mutate(
        aborted_play = dplyr::if_else(stringr::str_detect(.data$desc, 'Aborted'), 1, 0),
        #get rid of extraneous spaces that mess with player name finding
        #if there is a space or dash, and then a capital letter, and then a period, and then a space, take out the space
        desc = stringr::str_replace_all(.data$desc, "(((\\s)|(\\-))[A-Z]\\.)\\s+", "\\1"),
        success = dplyr::if_else(is.na(.data$epa), NA_real_, dplyr::if_else(.data$epa > 0, 1, 0)),
        passer = stringr::str_extract(.data$desc, glue::glue('{big_parser}{pass_finder}')),
        passer_jersey_number = stringr::str_extract(stringr::str_extract(.data$desc, glue::glue('{number_parser}{big_parser}{pass_finder}')), "[:digit:]*") %>% as.integer(),
        rusher = stringr::str_extract(.data$desc, glue::glue('{big_parser}{rush_finder}')),
        rusher_jersey_number = stringr::str_extract(stringr::str_extract(.data$desc, glue::glue('{number_parser}{big_parser}{rush_finder}')), "[:digit:]*") %>% as.integer(),
        #get rusher_player_name as a measure of last resort
        #finds things like aborted snaps and "F.Last to NYG 44."
        rusher = dplyr::if_else(
          is.na(.data$rusher) & is.na(.data$passer) & !is.na(.data$rusher_player_name), .data$rusher_player_name, .data$rusher
        ),
        receiver = stringr::str_extract(.data$desc, glue::glue('{receiver_finder}{big_parser}')),
        receiver_jersey_number = stringr::str_extract(stringr::str_extract(.data$desc, glue::glue('{receiver_number}{big_parser}')), "[:digit:]*") %>% as.integer(),
        #overwrite all these weird plays messing with the parser
        receiver = dplyr::case_when(
          stringr::str_detect(.data$desc, glue::glue('{abnormal_play}')) ~ .data$receiver_player_name,
          TRUE ~ .data$receiver
        ),
        rusher = dplyr::case_when(
          stringr::str_detect(.data$desc, glue::glue('{abnormal_play}')) ~ .data$rusher_player_name,
          TRUE ~ .data$rusher
        ),
        passer = dplyr::case_when(
          stringr::str_detect(.data$desc, glue::glue('{abnormal_play}')) ~ .data$passer_player_name,
          TRUE ~ .data$passer
        ),
        # fix the plays where scramble was fixed using charting data in 2005
        passer = dplyr::case_when(
          is.na(.data$passer) & .data$qb_scramble == 1 & !is.na(.data$rusher) & .data$season == 2005 ~ .data$rusher,
          TRUE ~ .data$passer
        ),
        # finally, for rusher, if there was already a passer (eg from scramble), set rusher to NA
        rusher = dplyr::if_else(
          !is.na(.data$passer), NA_character_, .data$rusher
        ),
        # if no pass is thrown, there shouldn't be a receiver
        receiver = dplyr::if_else(
          stringr::str_detect(.data$desc, ' pass '), .data$receiver, NA_character_
        ),
        # if there's a pass, sack, or scramble, it's a pass play...
        pass = dplyr::if_else(stringr::str_detect(.data$desc, "( pass )|(sacked)|(scramble)") | .data$qb_scramble == 1, 1, 0),
        # ...unless it says "backwards pass" and there's a rusher
        pass = dplyr::if_else(
          stringr::str_detect(.data$desc, "(backward pass)|(Backward pass)") & !is.na(.data$rusher),
          0, .data$pass
        ),
        # and make sure there's no pass on a kickoff (sometimes there's forward pass on kickoff but that's not a pass play)
        pass = dplyr::case_when(
          .data$kickoff_attempt == 1 ~ 0,
          TRUE ~ .data$pass
        ),
        #if there's a rusher and it wasn't a QB kneel or pass play, it's a run play
        rush = dplyr::if_else(!is.na(.data$rusher) & .data$qb_kneel == 0 & .data$pass == 0, 1, 0),
        #fix some common QBs with inconsistent names
        passer = dplyr::case_when(
          passer == "Jos.Allen" ~ "J.Allen",
          passer == "Alex Smith" | passer == "Ale.Smith" ~ "A.Smith",
          passer == "Ryan" & .data$posteam == "ATL" ~ "M.Ryan",
          passer == "Tr.Brown" ~ "T.Brown",
          passer == "Sh.Hill" ~ "S.Hill",
          passer == "Matt.Moore" | passer == "Mat.Moore" ~ "M.Moore",
          passer == "Jo.Freeman" ~ "J.Freeman",
          passer == "G.Minshew" ~ "G.Minshew II",
          passer == "R.Griffin" ~ "R.Griffin III",
          passer == "Randel El" ~ "A.Randle El",
          passer == "Randle El" ~ "A.Randle El",
          season <= 2003 & passer == "Van Pelt" ~ "A.Van Pelt",
          season > 2003 & passer == "Van Pelt" ~ "B.Van Pelt",
          passer == "Dom.Davis" ~ "D.Davis",
          TRUE ~ .data$passer
        ),
        rusher = dplyr::case_when(
          rusher == "D.Johnson" & posteam == "HOU" & season == 2020 & rusher_jersey_number == 31 ~ "Da.Johnson",
          rusher == "D.Johnson" & posteam == "HOU" & season == 2020 & rusher_jersey_number == 25 ~ "Du.Johnson",
          rusher == "Jos.Allen" ~ "J.Allen",
          rusher == "Alex Smith" | rusher == "Ale.Smith" ~ "A.Smith",
          rusher == "Ryan" & .data$posteam == "ATL" ~ "M.Ryan",
          rusher == "Tr.Brown" ~ "T.Brown",
          rusher == "Sh.Hill" ~ "S.Hill",
          rusher == "Matt.Moore" | rusher == "Mat.Moore" ~ "M.Moore",
          rusher == "Jo.Freeman" ~ "J.Freeman",
          rusher == "G.Minshew" ~ "G.Minshew II",
          rusher == "R.Griffin" ~ "R.Griffin III",
          rusher == "Randel El" ~ "A.Randle El",
          rusher == "Randle El" ~ "A.Randle El",
          season <= 2003 & rusher == "Van Pelt" ~ "A.Van Pelt",
          season > 2003 & rusher == "Van Pelt" ~ "B.Van Pelt",
          rusher == "Dom.Davis" ~ "D.Davis",
          TRUE ~ rusher
        ),
        receiver = dplyr::case_when(
          receiver == "F.R" ~ "F.Jones",
          TRUE ~ receiver
        ),
        first_down = dplyr::if_else(.data$first_down_rush == 1 | .data$first_down_pass == 1 | .data$first_down_penalty == 1, 1, 0),
        # easy filter: play is 1 if a "special teams" play, or 0 otherwise
        # with thanks to Lee Sharpe for the code
        special = dplyr::if_else(.data$play_type %in%
                                   c("extra_point","field_goal","kickoff","punt"), 1, 0),
        # easy filter: play is 1 if a "normal" play (including penalties), or 0 otherwise
        # with thanks to Lee Sharpe for the code
        play = dplyr::if_else(!is.na(.data$epa) & !is.na(.data$posteam) &
                                .data$desc != "*** play under review ***" &
                                substr(.data$desc,1,8) != "Timeout " &
                                .data$play_type %in% c("no_play","pass","run"),1,0)
      ) %>%
      #standardize team names (eg Chargers are always LAC even when they were playing in SD)
      dplyr::mutate_at(dplyr::vars(
        "posteam", "defteam", "home_team", "away_team", "timeout_team", "td_team", "return_team", "penalty_team",
        "side_of_field", "forced_fumble_player_1_team", "forced_fumble_player_2_team",
        "solo_tackle_1_team", "solo_tackle_2_team",
        "assist_tackle_1_team", "assist_tackle_2_team", "assist_tackle_3_team", "assist_tackle_4_team",
        "tackle_with_assist_1_team", "tackle_with_assist_2_team",
        "fumbled_1_team", "fumbled_2_team", "fumble_recovery_1_team", "fumble_recovery_2_team",
        "yrdln", "end_yard_line", "drive_start_yard_line", "drive_end_yard_line"
      ), team_name_fn) %>%
      
      #Seb's stuff for fixing player ids
      dplyr::mutate(index = 1 : dplyr::n()) %>% # to re-sort after all the group_bys
      
      dplyr::group_by(.data$passer, .data$posteam, .data$season) %>%
      dplyr::mutate(
        passer_id = dplyr::if_else(is.na(.data$passer), NA_character_, custom_mode(.data$passer_player_id))
      ) %>%
      
      dplyr::group_by(.data$passer_id) %>%
      dplyr::mutate(passer = dplyr::if_else(is.na(.data$passer_id), NA_character_, custom_mode(.data$passer))) %>%
      
      dplyr::group_by(.data$rusher, .data$posteam, .data$season) %>%
      dplyr::mutate(
        rusher_id = dplyr::if_else(is.na(.data$rusher), NA_character_, custom_mode(.data$rusher_player_id))
      ) %>%
      
      dplyr::group_by(.data$rusher_id) %>%
      dplyr::mutate(rusher = dplyr::if_else(is.na(.data$rusher_id), NA_character_, custom_mode(.data$rusher))) %>%
      
      dplyr::group_by(.data$receiver, .data$posteam, .data$season) %>%
      dplyr::mutate(
        receiver_id = dplyr::if_else(is.na(.data$receiver), NA_character_, custom_mode(.data$receiver_player_id))
      ) %>%
      
      dplyr::group_by(.data$receiver_id) %>%
      dplyr::mutate(receiver = dplyr::if_else(is.na(.data$receiver_id), NA_character_, custom_mode(.data$receiver))) %>%
      
      dplyr::ungroup() %>%
      dplyr::mutate(
        # if there's an aborted snap and qb didn't get a pass off,
        # then charge it to whoever charged with the fumble
        # this has to go after all the custom_mode stuff or it gets messed up
        rusher = dplyr::if_else(
          .data$aborted_play == 1 & is.na(.data$passer) & !is.na(.data$fumbled_1_player_name),
          .data$fumbled_1_player_name, .data$rusher
        ),
        rusher_id = dplyr::if_else(
          .data$aborted_play == 1 & is.na(.data$passer) & !is.na(.data$fumbled_1_player_id),
          .data$fumbled_1_player_id, .data$rusher_id
        ),
        
        name = dplyr::if_else(!is.na(.data$passer), .data$passer, .data$rusher),
        jersey_number = dplyr::if_else(!is.na(.data$passer_jersey_number), .data$passer_jersey_number, .data$rusher_jersey_number),
        id = dplyr::if_else(!is.na(.data$passer_id), .data$passer_id, .data$rusher_id)
      ) %>%
      dplyr::arrange(.data$index) %>%
      dplyr::select(-"index") %>%
      # add action player
      dplyr::mutate(
        fantasy_player_name = case_when(
          !is.na(.data$rusher_player_name) ~ .data$rusher_player_name,
          is.na(.data$rusher_player_name) & !is.na(.data$receiver_player_name) ~ .data$receiver_player_name,
          TRUE ~ NA_character_
        ),
        fantasy_player_id = case_when(
          !is.na(.data$rusher_player_id) ~ .data$rusher_player_id,
          is.na(.data$rusher_player_id) & !is.na(.data$receiver_player_id) ~ .data$receiver_player_id,
          TRUE ~ NA_character_
        ),
        fantasy = case_when(
          !is.na(.data$rusher) ~ .data$rusher,
          is.na(.data$rusher) & !is.na(.data$receiver) ~ .data$receiver,
          .data$qb_scramble == 1 ~ .data$passer,
          TRUE ~ NA_character_
        ),
        fantasy_id = case_when(
          !is.na(.data$rusher_id) ~ .data$rusher_id,
          is.na(.data$rusher_id) & !is.na(.data$receiver_id) ~ .data$receiver_id,
          .data$qb_scramble == 1 ~ .data$passer_id,
          TRUE ~ NA_character_
        ),
        out_of_bounds = dplyr::if_else(
          stringr::str_detect(.data$desc, "(ran ob)|(pushed ob)|(sacked ob)"), 1, 0
        )
      ) %>%
      dplyr::group_by(.data$game_id) %>%
      dplyr::mutate(
        home_opening_kickoff = dplyr::if_else(.data$home_team == dplyr::first(stats::na.omit(.data$posteam)), 1, 0)
      ) %>%
      dplyr::ungroup()
    
  }
  
  message_completed("Cleaning completed", ...)
  
  return(r)
}

#these things are used in clean_pbp() above

# look for First[period or space]Last[maybe - or ' in last][maybe more letters in last][maybe Jr. or II or IV]
big_parser <- "(?<=)[A-Z][A-z]*+(\\.|\\s)+[A-Z][A-z]*+\\'*\\-*[A-Z]*+[a-z]*+(\\s((Jr.)|(Sr.)|I{2,3})|(IV))?"
# maybe some spaces and letters, and then a rush direction unless they fumbled
rush_finder <- "(?=\\s*[a-z]*+\\s*((FUMBLES) | (left end)|(left tackle)|(left guard)|(up the middle)|(right guard)|(right tackle)|(right end)))"
# maybe some spaces and leters, and then pass / sack / scramble
pass_finder <- "(?=\\s*[a-z]*+\\s*(( pass)|(sack)|(scramble)))"
# to or for, maybe a jersey number and a dash
receiver_finder <- "(?<=((to)|(for))\\s[:digit:]{0,2}\\-{0,1})"
# weird play finder
abnormal_play <- "(Lateral)|(lateral)|(pitches to)|(Direct snap to)|(New quarterback for)|(Aborted)|(backwards pass)|(Pass back to)|(Flea-flicker)"
# look for 1-2 numbers before a dash
number_parser <- "((?<=)[:digit:]{1,2}(-))?"
# special case for receivers
receiver_number <- "(?<=((to)|(for))\\s)[:digit:]{0,2}\\-{0,1}"

# These columns are being generated by clean_pbp and the function tries to drop
# them in case it is being used on a pbp dataset where the columns already exist
drop.cols <- c(
  "success", "passer", "rusher", "receiver", "pass", "rush", "special",
  "first_down", "play", "passer_id", "rusher_id", "receiver_id", "name", "id",
  "passer_jersey_number", "rusher_jersey_number", "receiver_jersey_number",
  "jersey_number", "aborted_play", "fantasy", "fantasy_id", "fantasy_player_name",
  "fantasy_player_id", "out_of_bounds"
)

# fixes team names on columns with yard line
# example: 'SD 49' --> 'LAC 49'
# thanks to awgymer for the contribution:
# https://github.com/nflverse/nflfastR/issues/29#issuecomment-654592195
team_name_fn <- function(var) {
  stringr::str_replace_all(
    var,
    c(
      "JAC" = "JAX",
      "STL" = "LA",
      "SL" = "LA",
      "ARZ" = "ARI",
      "BLT" = "BAL",
      "CLV" = "CLE",
      "HST" = "HOU",
      "SD" = "LAC",
      "OAK" = "LV"
    )
  )
}

#' Compute QB epa
#'
#' @inheritParams clean_pbp
#' @details Add the variable 'qb_epa', which gives QB credit for EPA for up to the point where
#' a receiver lost a fumble after a completed catch and makes EPA work more
#' like passing yards on plays with fumbles
#' @export
add_qb_epa <- function(pbp, ...) {
  
  if (nrow(pbp) == 0) {
    user_message("Nothing to do. Return passed data frame.", "info")
  } else {
    # drop existing values of clean_pbp
    pbp <- pbp %>% dplyr::select(-tidyselect::any_of("qb_epa"))
    
    fumbles_df <- pbp %>%
      dplyr::filter(.data$complete_pass == 1 & .data$fumble_lost == 1 & !is.na(.data$epa) & !is.na(.data$down)) %>%
      dplyr::mutate(
        half_seconds_remaining = dplyr::if_else(
          .data$half_seconds_remaining <= 6,
          0,
          .data$half_seconds_remaining - 6
        ),
        down = as.numeric(.data$down),
        # save old stuff for testing/checking
        posteam_timeouts_pre = .data$posteam_timeouts_remaining,
        defeam_timeouts_pre = .data$defteam_timeouts_remaining,
        down_old = .data$down,
        ydstogo_old = .data$ydstogo,
        epa_old = .data$epa,
        # update yard line, down, yards to go from play result
        yardline_100 = .data$yardline_100 - .data$yards_gained,
        down = dplyr::if_else(.data$yards_gained >= .data$ydstogo, 1, .data$down + 1),
        # if the fumble spot would have resulted in turnover on downs, need to give other team the ball and fix
        change = dplyr::if_else(.data$down == 5, 1, 0), down = dplyr::if_else(.data$down == 5, 1, .data$down),
        # yards to go is 10 if its a first down, update otherwise
        ydstogo = dplyr::if_else(.data$down == 1, 10, .data$ydstogo - .data$yards_gained),
        # 10 yards to go if possession change
        ydstogo = dplyr::if_else(.data$change == 1, 10, .data$ydstogo),
        # flip field and timeouts for possession change
        yardline_100 = dplyr::if_else(.data$change == 1, 100 - .data$yardline_100, .data$yardline_100),
        posteam_timeouts_remaining = dplyr::if_else(.data$change == 1,
                                                    .data$defeam_timeouts_pre,
                                                    .data$posteam_timeouts_pre),
        defteam_timeouts_remaining = dplyr::if_else(.data$change == 1,
                                                    .data$posteam_timeouts_pre,
                                                    .data$defeam_timeouts_pre),
        # fix yards to go for goal line (eg can't have 1st & 10 inside opponent 10 yard line)
        ydstogo = dplyr::if_else(.data$yardline_100 < .data$ydstogo, .data$yardline_100, .data$ydstogo),
        ep_old = .data$ep
      ) %>%
      dplyr::select(
        "game_id", "play_id",
        "season", "home_team", "posteam", "roof", "half_seconds_remaining",
        "yardline_100", "down", "ydstogo",
        "posteam_timeouts_remaining", "defteam_timeouts_remaining",
        "down_old", "ep_old", "change"
      )
    
    if (nrow(fumbles_df) > 0) {
      new_ep_df <- calculate_expected_points(fumbles_df) %>%
        dplyr::mutate(ep = dplyr::if_else(.data$change == 1, -.data$ep, .data$ep), fixed_epa = .data$ep - .data$ep_old) %>%
        dplyr::select("game_id", "play_id", "fixed_epa")
      
      pbp <- pbp %>%
        dplyr::left_join(new_ep_df, by = c("game_id", "play_id")) %>%
        dplyr::mutate(qb_epa = dplyr::if_else(!is.na(.data$fixed_epa), .data$fixed_epa, .data$epa)) %>%
        dplyr::select(-"fixed_epa")
    } else {
      pbp <- pbp %>% dplyr::mutate(qb_epa = .data$epa)
    }
  }
  
  message_completed("added qb_epa", ...)
  
  return(pbp)
}

    mutate(Pass_Defense_WAS = case_when(play_type == "pass" & defteam == "WAS" ~ 1,
                                        play_type != "pass" & defteam != "WAS" ~ 0))
  
  return(ridge_variables)
}

                 "nflfastr_pbp")
pbp_fastr <- as.data.frame(pbp_fastr) %>%
  filter(season_type == "REG", season == 2020) %>%
  Clean_pbp()


## READ IN SEPARATE ROSTER DATA & CREATE NAME ABBREVIATION

read_roster_csv <- function(year){
  read_csv(url(glue::glue('https://raw.githubusercontent.com/mrcaseb/nflfastR-roster/master/data/seasons/roster_{year}.csv')))
}

all_roster <- 1999:2021 %>% 
  purrr::map_dfr(read_roster_csv)

all_roster <- all_roster %>% 
  mutate(Abbr = paste(substr(full_name, start = 1, stop = 1), last_name, sep = ".")) %>%
  dplyr::select(Season = season, Team = team, Position = position, Depth_Chart = depth_chart_position,
         Jersey = jersey_number, Full_Name = full_name, First_Name = first_name, Last_Name = last_name,
         Abbr, gsis_id, pff_id, sportradar_id, headshot_url) %>%
  mutate(Team = case_when(Team == "STL" ~ "LA",
                          Team == "OAK" ~ "LV",
                          Team == "SD" ~ "LAC",
                          TRUE ~ Team)) %>%
  write_rds("/Users/dylanmervis/Google Drive/1999-2021_roster_raw.rds")

  filter(rush == 1 & is.na(Rusher)) %>%
  dplyr::select(season, posteam, desc, rusher_player_name, rusher_id, rush, penalty)

  group_by(rusher_player_name, rusher_id, season, posteam) %>%
  summarise(rush = sum(rush)) %>%
  filter(rush > 20) %>%
  left_join(skill_roster, by = c("rusher_id" = "gsis_id")) %>%
  distinct(rusher_player_name, season, Full_Name, .keep_all = TRUE) %>%
  ungroup()

ridge_variables <- pbp_ridge %>%

                                               "Defensive Holding", "Defensive Pass Interference",
                                               "Defensive Offside", "Unneccessary Roughness",
                                               "Horse Collar Tackle", 
                                               "Lowering the Head to Initiate Contact")) %>%
  mutate(yards_to_go_square = ydstogo * ydstogo,
         yards_times_down = ydstogo * down,
         yardline_squared = yardline_100^2,
         vegas_wp_squared = vegas_wp * vegas_wp,
         log_vegas_wp = log(vegas_wp),
         side_of_field_indicator = if_else(posteam == side_of_field, 1, 0)) %>%
  filter(pass == 1) %>%
  filter(season == {year}) %>%
  mutate(epa = round(epa * ((1 - 0.025) ^ (17 - week)), digits = 4)) %>%
  mutate(epa = if_else(week == 17 & vegas_wp > 0.85, epa * 0.25, epa)) %>%
  mutate(epa = if_else(wp >= 0.015 & wp <= 0.985, epa, epa * 0.12)) %>%
  left_join(Qbs_Priors_PORP, by = c("Passer" = "Name", "season" = "Season")) %>%
  left_join(Wrs_Priors_PORP, by = c("Receiver" = "Name", "season" = "Season")) %>% ## PRIORS JOINED
  mutate(Total_Weight = case_when(!is.na(Pass_Weight) & !is.na(Receiving_Weight) ~ 
                                    (Receiving_Weight - Pass_Weight) * ((1 - 0.025) ^ (17 - week)),
                                  !is.na(Pass_Weight) & is.na(Receiving_Weight) ~ 
                                    Pass_Weight * ((1 - 0.025) ^ (17 - week)),
                                  is.na(Pass_Weight) & !is.na(Receiving_Weight) ~ 
                                    Receiving_Weight * ((1 - 0.025) ^ (17 - week)),
                                  TRUE ~ 0)) %>%
  mutate(Total_Weight = if_else(week == 17 & vegas_wp > 0.85, Total_Weight * 0.25, Total_Weight)) %>%
  mutate(Total_Weight = if_else(wp >= 0.015 & wp <= 0.985, Total_Weight, Total_Weight * 0.12)) %>%
  mutate(epa = round(epa - Receiving_Weight, digits = 4))

  mutate(R_Perc = case_when(Name == "Lamar Jackson" ~ 0.85,
                            Name == "Kyler Murray" ~ 0.40,

  mutate(R_Perc = if_else(R_Perc > 1, 1, R_Perc)) %>%

                           + ((Total_R_Perc*100 - 25)* .015), digits = 2)) %>%
  mutate(Adj_R_RTG = round((Adj_R_RTG / (mean_rg / 8 / .25)) * (Rush_Per_Game / mean_rg), digits = 2))

## A Primer On Regularized Adjusted Plus-Minus (RAPM) & Expected Points Added (EPA)

In order to understand what I'm attempting to apply to play-by-play football data, it is first important to grasp the concepts of RAPM and EPA. I'll provide a brief explanation here without all of the technical details, and then link a bunch of articles that explain both concepts in much greater depth than I do.

Ridge Regression has been utilized to measure players in the three major North American sports excluding football. Baseball utilizes the statistical method to create various metrics like Tom Tango's Weighted On-Base Percentage (wOBA), while hockey and basketball mainly use ridge regression to create Ridge Adjusted Plus-Minus (RAPM) models. RAPM was initially developed as a methodology to better evaluate NBA players. It has since become the leading public framework for estimating a given player's value in both the NBA and NHL. The reason I say "public" is because the teams themselves have access to much more sophisticated data, so I have no clue if they utilize the same methodologies. There are many different versions of this type of regression analysis, but fundamentally the goal of each is to isolate a player's individual contributions independent of all other factors that may impact performance. The way to do this is to use the data that the league provides, create a column for each player as a predictor (independent variables), and regress this upon the target variable (dependent variable). For example, in the NFL the data is delivered in a play-by-play format in a large data set with each row of data representing one play containing ~300 variables. In order to apply the regression, columns for each player are created as dummy variables with value 1 if the player is on the field, and value 0 if the player is not on the field. These variables for each player, along with contextual variables for each play are then regressed on to EPA, which results in a coefficient for each player. The player coefficients are interpreted as each player's individual contribution in terms of points per play. I will run through this whole process again later on in the article with some code to help with visualization.

Ridge Regression works very well in basketball and hockey because it introduces bias into each player's coefficient estimate in order to reduce the overall variance within the model. This is helpful because it reduces the multi-collinearity that standard least squares regression would be fooled by. As an example, if an NBA player plays only 5 minutes per game, but all of those minutes are played with LeBron James then linear regression will most likely interpret that player as very efficient, despite the efficiency simply being a product of playing with LeBron. The regularization techniques of ridge regression will be able to better decipher which of the two players is actually providing more value to the team due to the biasing of coefficients. The resulting effect is that the player's RAPM coefficient will be shrunk towards zero (due to the lack of minutes) much greater than LeBron's. The amount of shrinkage applied to each of the coefficients is determined through the tuning of the lambda parameter, which is basically a fancy way of saying that a player will be penalized for playing fewer minutes, and exclusively playing with LeBron. A large lambda results in more shrinkage towards zero, while a lambda of zero will produce identical results to linear regression since there will be zero shrinkage applied to the coefficient estimates.

This was an *extremely* simple overview of RAPM, and it is borderline criminal how much I summarized. I'll build on this and get more technical in the future, but in the meantime here are some links that provide excellent details. I would start with the Evolving Wild article:

* A comprehensive RAPM overview with applications to hockey: [Evolving Wild](https://hockey-graphs.com/2019/01/14/reviving-regularized-adjusted-plus-minus-for-hockey/)
* Series of articles detailing the process of building a RAPM model: [TopDown Hockey](https://towardsdatascience.com/building-venue-adjusted-rapm-for-expected-goals-the-origin-the-process-and-the-results-part-2-9245ae51e23d)
* Another hockey focused RAPM model: [The Bucketless](https://thebucketless.wordpress.com/2021/01/28/usage-informed-rapm/)
* Explanation of Daily Adjusted and Regressed Kalman Optimized projections for basketball: [Darko](https://apanalytics.shinyapps.io/DARKO/)
* Technical notes on Penalized Regression Models [Lasso & Ridge](https://cran.r-project.org/web/packages/penalized/vignettes/penalized.pdf)


Luckily for the reader, EPA is a much simpler concept than penalized regression methods. The fundamental idea behind EPA is easy to grasp: a 3-yard rush on 4th down & 1 at the 50 is not the same thing as a 3-yard rush on 1st & 20 from your own 4 yard line, so they should not be treated equally. At its simplest form EPA adds context to plays and weights the probabilities of all the possible outcomes for the next score. As an example, suppose the game setting is 1st & 10 on the 50 yard line and historically teams in this situation score an *average* of 2 points (made up number). 2 is your expected points. On the following play the team scores a touchdown, so the expected points *added* is 6 and some change (since extra points are not guaranteed) - 2 points. EPA is awesome for many reason, and has become the fundamental way to analyze football plays. Additionally, it is easily adjustable for any contextual variables that the data set allows and it is already in terms of points, which historically and for the foreseeable future is how you win football games. Again, this is an over-simplification which will be built upon later, so here is some further reading:

* The full original EPA framework powerpoint: [NFL Player Evaluation Using Expected Points Added with nflscrapR](https://www.stat.cmu.edu/~ryurko/files/greatlakes_2017.pdf)
* The current torch holders of NFL play-by-play scraping and the base EPA that we will be adjusting: [nflfastR EP models](https://www.opensourcefootball.com/posts/2020-09-28-nflfastr-ep-wp-and-cp-models/)


## Application to the NFL

Now that we've run through the basics we can get into the project that I have been working on. Keep in mind that the results and process are severely limited by my lack of understanding of what I am doing. Application of RAPM to the NFL is tricky due to the fundamental differences between basketball/hockey and football. In hockey/basketball there are five players with the common goal of either putting the puck/basketball in the goal/net, or defending the puck/ball from entering the goal/net. Aside from the goalie, these sports are much more fluid than football with the positions and roles of the various players. You would never see Patrick Mahomes lined up in the slot unless it is a gimmick play, but you will see any given NBA player shoot, rebound, pass, etc. This is why I decided to apply RAPM individually to passing, rushing, and receiving. I am currently working on the same process for the defensive side of the ball, and with more granular charting data that I scraped from SportRadar, I plan to apply RAPM to both pass blocking and run blocking. 

Unfortunately ridge regression is not without it's flaws, especially when applied to football, and it would be misleading if I did not outline them:

1. For all plays, the NFL play-by-play data will include the passer, rusher, receiver, and the nearest defender. This is problematic given that there are 22 players on the field that we are attempting to adjust for. I had scraped the participation data feed from SportRadar, which contained all 22 players on the field for each play, but that data feed was recently taken down so I am out of luck.
2. The nature of football and positional value creates issues for ridge regression. It is well known that the Quarterback is far and away the most valuable player on the field. However, when creating a RAPM of passing, rushing, and receiving all in one (which would be ideal) ridge regression would pretty much just de-value QB's and add value to rushers and receivers. This is why I made the decision to create three RAPM models, which has it's own side effect of not effectively reducing multi-collinearity as much as I would hope.
3. Sample size issues. Pretty much all analysis focused on the NFL outside of tracking data suffers from a lack of a large enough sample.

Despite all the above issues, RAPM is still effective in analyzing NFL players as it is a mostly objective way to adjust EPA and create player coefficients by comparing each player to one another. The most obvious application that I can think of given the current attainability of play-by-play/charting data would be a RAPM model including all receivers and defensive backs. Anyways, now that I have undermined the whole project, let's get into it starting with adjusting EPA. The base EPA that I am utilizing is located in the nflfastR package created and updated by Ben Baldwin and Sebastian Carl. Their EPA model adjusts for:

* Seconds remaining in the half
* Yardline
* Whether the possession team is also the home team
* Roof type (retractable, dome, outdoors)
* Down
* Yards to go
* Era: 1999:2001 (pre - Houston Texans), 2002:2005 (pre - usage of the Completion Percentage Over Expected stat), 2006:2013, 2014:2017, 2018:Present
* Timeouts remaining for each team

This is a great start, but can be made more predictive by adjusting for additional variables. In order to determine which of these additional variables are significant I ran a Lasso regression model to select the variables. A Lasso regression model is very similar to a Ridge regression model with the main difference being that Lasso will fully regress coefficients it deems insignificant to zero, effectively throwing them out of the model. Ridge regression will never fully regress a coefficient to exactly zero, which is useful because remember that each player has their own coefficient that should not be thrown out. Here is what the lasso looks like in R:

```{r, eval=FALSE}
## pbp_ridge is my full play-by-play data set of each NFL season from 1999:2020. What I am doing here with mutate() is creating a bunch of variables that I think may be significant to adjust EPA with that I can then test within the Lasso model.
pbp_edit <- pbp_ridge %>%
  filter(season >= 1999) %>%
  mutate(yards_to_go_square = ydstogo * ydstogo,
         yards_times_down = ydstogo * down,
         wp_squared = wp^2,
         log_wp = log(wp),
         log_ydstogo = log(ydstogo),
         yardline_squared = yardline_100^2,
         gtg_down = down * goal_to_go,
         vegas_wp_squared = vegas_wp * vegas_wp,
         log_vegas_wp = log(vegas_wp),
         home = if_else(posteam == home_team, 1, 0),
         side_of_field_indicator = if_else(posteam == side_of_field, 1, 0),
         in_red_zone = if_else(yardline_100 <= 20, 1, 0),
         in_fg_range = if_else(yardline_100 <= 35, 1, 0)) 

lasso_epa_table <- pbp_edit %>%
  dplyr::select(epa)

lasso_dataset <- pbp_edit %>%
  dplyr::select(down, ydstogo, yardline_100, wp, shotgun, qtr, half_seconds_remaining, goal_to_go,
         home, no_huddle, total_line, drive_play_count, series, posteam_timeouts_remaining, gtg_down, 
         defteam_timeouts_remaining, wind, yards_to_go_square, yards_times_down, 
         wp_squared, log_wp, log_ydstogo, yardline_squared, vegas_wp_squared, log_vegas_wp,
         side_of_field_indicator, ydstogo, in_red_zone, in_fg_range)

```

This is the full Lasso data set, which includes all of the variables that I am testing, and each play from every game since 1999 excluding special teams and Week 1 St. Louis Rams vs. Baltimore Ravens. I haven't figured out why that game is missing yet.

```{r, echo = FALSE}
dim(lasso_dataset)
```

Here is the code for the actual Lasso model. In order to run a Ridge model, simply change the alpha parameter from 1 to 0.
```{r, eval = FALSE}
lasso_epa_vector <- as.vector(lasso_epa_table)
lasso_epa_vector[is.na(lasso_epa_vector)] <- 0
lasso_context_vector <- as.vector(lasso_dataset)
lasso_context_vector[is.na(lasso_context_vector)] <- 0

lasso_epa_matrix = as.matrix(as.data.frame(lapply(lasso_epa_vector, as.numeric)))
lasso_context_matrix = as.matrix(as.data.frame(lapply(lasso_context_vector, as.numeric)))

lambdas_to_try <- 10^seq(-3, 5, length.out = 100)

lambda_seq <- 10^seq(2, -2, by = -.1)

## SET SEED, SPLIT DATA FOR TRAINING & TESTING
set.seed(2021)

train = sample(1:nrow(lasso_context_matrix), nrow(lasso_context_matrix)*.75)
x_test = (-train)
y_test = lasso_epa_matrix[x_test]

## FIT THE LASSO TO EPA UTILIZING THE CONTEXT VARIABLES
library(glmnet)
library(tidyr)
library(broom)

# 10-FOLD CROSS VALIDATION TO OPTIMIZE THE LAMBDA PARAMETER
cv_output <- cv.glmnet(lasso_context_matrix[train,], lasso_epa_matrix[train],
                       alpha = 1, lambda = lambda_seq, 
                       nfolds = 10)

## SELECT THE BEST LAMBDA. FOR RIDGE USE lambda.min, FOR LASSO USE lambda.1se
## WHY? IDK, SOMEONE MUCH SMARTER THAN ME SAYS SO
best_lam <- cv_output$lambda.1se
best_lam

lasso_best <- glmnet(lasso_context_matrix[train,], lasso_epa_matrix[train], alpha = 1, lambda = best_lam)
pred <- predict(lasso_best, s = best_lam, newx = lasso_context_matrix[x_test,])

final <- cbind(lasso_epa_matrix[test], pred)
```

In order to better display the variables that Lasso selected, this is each of them in a linear regression model.
```{r, echo=FALSE}
## STANDARD LINEAR REGRESSION WITH EACH VARIABLE THAT LASSO SELECTED

context_regression <- lm(data=pbp_edit, epa ~ yardline_100 + total_line + shotgun + qtr +
                           drive_play_count +  yardline_squared + side_of_field_indicator +
                           vegas_wp_squared + log_vegas_wp + defteam_timeouts_remaining)
summary(context_regression)
```

Considering that we are adjusting EPA for contextual variables without any data on what actually occurred within the given play, this is a decent start. To further prove that what we just did is actually useful, I rebuilt the XGBoost EP Model that Ben Baldwin was kind enough to share in the nflfastrR EP Model article that I linked earlier. From here we can perform the calibration measures utilized by Ron Yurko, Sam Ventura, and Maxim Horowitz (creators of nflscrapR).

This is important when predicting and adjusting EPA because it should be taken into account that it was much more difficult to score the 2013 Legion of Boom Seattle Seahawks defense, than the 2020 2-14 Jacksonville Jaguars defense.


## RAPM Model Set-Up

Now that we've defined everything that we will be adjusting for, we can get into model setup and results. I will use the script for creating passing value metrics in 2020. Here's the initial set up:
```{r, eval = FALSE}
## START RIDGE ADJUSTMENTS & ADD DUMMY VARIABLES

year <- 2020

ridge_variables <- pbp_ridge %>%
  filter(!is.na(penalty) | penalty_type %in% c("Defensive Offside", "Intentional Grounding", 
                                               "Encroachment", "Neutral Zone Infraction",
                                               "Delay of Game", "Inelgible Downfield Pass", 
                                               "Unneccessary Roughness",
                                               "Offensive Too Many Men on Field")) %>%
  mutate(yards_to_go_square = ydstogo * ydstogo,
         yards_times_down = ydstogo * down,
         yardline_squared = yardline_100^2,
         vegas_wp_squared = vegas_wp * vegas_wp,
         log_vegas_wp = log(vegas_wp),
         side_of_field_indicator = if_else(posteam == side_of_field, 1, 0)) %>%
  filter(season == {year}) %>%
  mutate(epa = round(epa * ((1 - 0.025) ^ (17 - week)), digits = 4)) %>%
  mutate(epa = if_else(week == 17 & vegas_wp > 0.85, epa * 0.25, epa)) %>%
  mutate(epa = if_else(wp >= 0.015 & wp <= 0.985, epa, epa * 0.12)) %>%
  left_join(Qbs_Priors_PORP, by = c("Passer" = "Name", "season" = "Season")) %>%
  left_join(Rbs_Priors_PORP, by = c("Rusher" = "Name", "season" = "Season")) %>%
  left_join(Wrs_Priors_PORP, by = c("Receiver" = "Name", "season" = "Season")) %>% ## PRIORS JOINED
  mutate(Total_Weight = case_when(!is.na(Pass_Weight) & !is.na(Receiving_Weight) ~ 
                                    (Pass_Weight - Receiving_Weight) * ((1 - 0.025) ^ (17 - week)),
                                  !is.na(Pass_Weight) & is.na(Receiving_Weight) ~ 
                                    Pass_Weight * ((1 - 0.025) ^ (17 - week)),
                                  is.na(Pass_Weight) & !is.na(Receiving_Weight) ~ 
                                    Receiving_Weight * ((1 - 0.025) ^ (17 - week)),
                                  TRUE ~ 0)) %>%
  mutate(Total_Weight = if_else(week == 17 & vegas_wp > 0.85, Total_Weight * 0.25, Total_Weight)) %>%
  mutate(Total_Weight = if_else(wp >= 0.015 & wp <= 0.985, Total_Weight, Total_Weight * 0.12)) %>%
  mutate(epa = round(epa - Pass_Weight, digits = 4))

ridge_variables <- ridge_variables %>%
  make_passer_mutations()
```

The first line filters out all penalties except for the ones that are listed in quotations. Why did I select to keep those penalties? I'm not sure, that is just what made sense to me at the time (You will notice that arbitrary decisions/statistics account for much of this analysis). Another thing to note is that the Priors are generated by running a vanilla RAPM on the first year of the data set (1999), and utilizing that output as the prior for the next season. This creates what is called a daisy chain with each year influenced by the previous years. Additionally, you can see in the code above that I adjust both EPA and the Priors for multiple situations. These include an exponential decay model to increase the importance of recent performance, an indicator that if it is week 17 and win probability is greater than 85% to decrease the importance of the play, and an indicator that if it is garbage time to down weight as well. The last thing I do is subtract EPA by the Prior of the passer involved in the play. The reason I do this is because ridge regression will now shrink each player's coefficient to their Prior, rather than shrink to zero. Since I subtract from EPA, I will then have to add each Prior back to EPA after the regression is run.

Next up comes the fun part. I add a dummy variable for every passer that has thrown >= 30 passes in a season since 1999. There are a lot more running backs and wide receivers than quarterbacks, so you can imagine how long and tedious this process is, especially when there are duplicate names. Here's what one line looks like for a quarterback:
```{r, eval = FALSE}
mutate(Passer_Troy_Aikman = case_when(Passer == "Troy Aikman" ~ 1,
                                        Passer != "Troy Aikman" ~ 0))
```
All this is doing is creating a dummy column in the model data set called "Passer_Troy_Aikman", which takes the value of 1 when the passer within the play is Troy Aikman, and takes the value of 0 when any other player is passing the ball. I repeat this for every player and team defense to create a very large data set of 1's and 0's. After this process is all said and done we will have the final model data set, which I can break into separate vectors of EPA (what we are regressing on), model variables, and weights. The weights are created by taking the passer's prior and subtracting the receiver's prior in order to adjust for receiver talent. The model itself looks very similar to the Lasso from earlier because it is the same glmnet R package. As I mentioned, we just have to switch the Alpha parameter from 1 to 0 to identify ridge regression, and solve for lambda.min, rather than lambda.1se. I run the regression both with weights and without them:
```{r, eval = FALSE}
## WORKING SEQUENCE LAMBDAS
lambdas_to_try <- 10^seq(-3, 5, length.out = 100)

set.seed(01061997)

lambda_seq <- 10^seq(2, -2, by = -.1)


fit <- glmnet(model_final, epa_final, alpha = 0, 
              lambda = lambdas_to_try, parallel = TRUE)
summary(fit)

ridge_cv <- cv.glmnet(model_final, epa_final, alpha = 0, nfolds = 10, weights = weights_final,
                      parallel = TRUE) ## ADD WEIGHTS AFTER CREATING
best_lambda_season <- ridge_cv$lambda.min
best_lambda_season

best_fit <- ridge_cv$glmnet.fit
head(best_fit)

best_ridge_season <- glmnet(model_final, epa_final, alpha = 0, lambda = best_lambda_season,
                            weights = weights_final, parallel = TRUE)
```

## Final Thoughts
This RAPM model is a start, but as previously mentioned, a lot more data needs to become publicly available to truly see the benefit of ridge regression applied to the NFL. The immediate next steps would be to repeat this process for all players to create the full player data set, and then build a Statistical Plus-Minus (SPM) model to predict the RAPM outputs. An SPM model is beneficial when working with RAPM because it utilizes commonly available statistics to predict RAPM, and allows for comparison year over year. This will create comparable player ratings across time horizons for the purpose of determining overvalued and undervalued players.
Along with the RAPM model, I am currently working on multiple multilevel models similar to the ones that the [nflWAR]("https://arxiv.org/pdf/1802.00998.pdf") team utilized. I should be able to ensemble individual model outputs in order to create a more robust player estimate.


Any feedback would be greatly appreciated and I would be happy to test any suggestions, but here are my initial thoughts on how to improve:

* Utilize age curves when building Priors.
* Add the SportRadar data into the Lasso database in order to better adjust EPA for additional contextual variables.
* Focus on individual RAPM's that may be more immediately applicable given the current data (Receivers and Defensive Backs). 
* Repeat the same RAPM process for individual offensive line, pass rushers, individual run defense,
and defensive backs. Some potential drawbacks to this would be that the analysis will focus only on plays in which the defender was involved. For example, it is well known that Jalen Ramsey is one of the top CB's in the league. At times he takes away half of the field because a QB might not throw the ball his way. I have no way of quantifying this impact with the current data set.
* Build the SPM/BPM model to predict RAPM. This will help with future prediction and team ratings.
* Translate points to wins by solving for Pythagorean exponent
* Increase granularity by creating coefficients for where players lineup. For example, a coefficient for Stefon Diggs in the slot, wide left, and wide right. This will be immediately useful for teams to identify optimal positional lineups, and for discovering overvalued and undervalued players in certain roles. Again, this will require more data to become public.
